captions.text:
Well, Konami certainly seem to be in the doghouse
still, going by the reaction to Metal Gear
Survive when it came out.

A sort of collective &quot;Oh look what the cat
dragged in.

Sure you can deign to hang out in video game
land a moment longer?

You wouldn&#39;t rather be making a fucking pachinko
machine based on a property people used to
like?

Oh look over there, Konami, an attractive
single Silent Hill game standing at the bar.

Why don&#39;t you swagger over there, put your
best game face on and fucking cancel it.&quot;

But it seems despite the ejection of Hideo
Kojima, Konami still hate making video games

slightly less than they hate not making buckets
of cash, so annoyingly the initials &#39;MGS&#39;
can now stand for two different things.

But perhaps we should put our universal seething
hatred for Konami aside and judge Metal Gear
Survive by its own merits.

After all, Konami could turn all this negative
feeling around in an instant.

All they have to do is make Silent Hill 2,
3 and 4 available on Steam.

Seriously, guys, Silent Hill Homecoming&#39;s
on there but not the good ones?

That&#39;s like giving extra pocket money to your
stunted brain damaged child who lives in the
basement with a cat on their head.

The point is, if that happens then we&#39;ll all
feel pretty silly about this kneejerk Konami

hatred when historians of the future look
back at Metal Gear Survive and think &quot;Well

it&#39;s not THAT bad, it&#39;s a little boring and
old hat but burning down the studio was still
pretty disproportionate.&quot;

Most of the objection to Metal Gear Survive
seems to come from the description of it before
anyone actually played the thing.

And admittedly it&#39;s not the kind of elevator
pitch that makes the CEO slam the emergency

stop button and drop to his knees there and
then for a worshipful gob job.

It&#39;s a Metal Gear game without Hideo Kojima,
which in itself is a sticking point because

Hideo Kojima&#39;s is an utterly unique mind that
no one has yet managed to convincingly channel,

ho yes, it takes more than insane conspiracies,
diarrhoea jokes and horrendously abused women

in completely inappropriate clothing, it&#39;s
all that but genuinely taking yourself seriously
as well.

So it&#39;s Metal Gear without Kojima, and also
they&#39;ve stripped out the traditional stealth

action and replaced it with zombies and bog
standard survival-crafting mechanics with

the usual triple-A live service quantification
bullshit that means it can be a fucking micropayment

safari but hey, put those molotovs down because
we&#39;re only gonna charge you forty bucks for
the privilege of wasting your life with it.
Talk about a fucking soft sell.

The plot is, you were one of Big Boss&#39; pet
gophers who hung around on his party boat

at the time of MGSV Ground Zeros when it got
blown up by bad guys jealous that they didn&#39;t

get invited to the pizza party, but it turns
out after Big Boss fucked off a giant wormhole

to another dimension opened in the sky and
started sucking up the survivors.

See, you&#39;ve fucked it up already, Metal Gear
Survive.

Hideo Kojima would have built things up for
at least forty-five minutes before he pulled

out the transdimensional wormhole shit, with
lots of stock footage of people walking down

crowded streets having very serious thoughts
about transdimensional wormholes.

Our custom protagonist, although whatever
appearance options you pick there is no escaping

from looking like Generic Grizzled Person
#84 because Big Boss&#39; hiring practices discriminated

heavily against the non-grizzle, must now
mount an expedition into the other dimension

in order to plunder its resources or something,
&#39;cos that&#39;s American foreign policy for ya.

But it soon becomes clear once you get there
that the other Earth is a desolate and hostile

place with not much to plunder unless you&#39;re
short on zombies, and I think I speak for

the entire entertainment industry when I say
we really fucking aren&#39;t.

God bless &#39;em, they do try to keep the spirit
of Metal Gear alive.

Most of the exposition happens in prolonged
back and forth dialogs, there&#39;s still stealth

gameplay, and the first major female NPC you
run into wears a sexy nurse outfit the whole

game for no particular reason, but it&#39;s just
not the same.

The sexy nurse doesn&#39;t have an even remotely
horrifically traumatic past, the dialogue

scenes never take longer than a few minutes
and don&#39;t always reiterate the same point

over and over again, and as for the stealth
- while you can sneak up on enemies and stealth

kill them with a knife to the bonce, they&#39;re
fucking zombies.

They&#39;re not gonna call HQ for fire support,
you can outrun them by maintaining a brisk
walk.

You can stealth kill them even if they&#39;re
alert, which leads to this humiliating little
barn dance as you try to get behind them again.

So anyone expecting a Metal Gear game from
such trifling evidence as the words &#39;Metal&#39;

and &#39;Gear&#39; appearing in the title is probably
going to be disappointed, because it feels

like they scooped out about one fifth of Metal
Gear Solid V and tried to stretch it out into

a full game until its bones snapped and its
tights had more ladders than a clearance sale
at the fire department.

So now that all the Metal Gear fans have pissed
off to put on their best Otacon face and cry

at the loss of their true love for the umpteenth
time, let&#39;s consider Metal Gear Survive by
its own merits.

The core gameplay is the Subnautica model,
explore hostile environment, find stuff, craft

upgrades with the stuff you find that expands
your base and widens the area you can explore,

plot unfolds as you go, it&#39;s all about unfolding
and expanding and widening like an American
tourist taking their shirt off at the beach.

The main difference between it and Subnautica
of course is that in Subnautica there were

lots of pretty things to look at, whereas
Metal Gear Survive&#39;s sightseeing tour covers

mostly blasted deserted hellscapes occasionally
livened up with featureless grey screen because
the entire world is shrouded in dust.

Except for in a few rigidly walled-off fresh
air ghettos where the last remnants of life

on the planet live carefree lives of gambolling
about lush meadows in the sun until you track

them down and knife them all to death because
you need the meat.

Yes, the &#39;survive&#39; part of Metal Gear Survive
really isn&#39;t fucking about.

As well as watching your limited air supply
in the dust storm you metabolise like a fucking

deep sea oil spill and have to be constantly
finding food, and animals don&#39;t respawn nearly

as often as I&#39;d like, the selfish, delicious
little bastards.

Besides survival and exploration, the other
main mechanic is tower defense.

Every now and again you have to defend a point
from a fucking conga line of zombies by setting

up barricades at choke points so you can stand
just behind it and swat them off with a stick,

like it&#39;s Black Friday at the crystal meth
shop.

And I have to admit, after one of these where
I had to defend the point for a whole fifteen

minutes until I was down to holding them off
with handfuls of gravel and tactical farts,

I was pretty invigorated by my victory, if
not by the thought of the subsequent prolonged

shopping trip to the wilderness to re-craft
all my fucking ammo again.

So, if you can disregard the motives with
which this game was made, i.e., all the kids

in the triple A club are making loads of money
with their shitty Skinner box &#39;live service&#39;

games, let&#39;s stitch one of our own together
from about five hundred generic ideas that

other games have done better, slap on the
name of a franchise we haven&#39;t quite milked

all the goodwill from yet, set up the micropayments
and hook ourselves a couple of whales, then

Metal Gear Survive reaches the dizzy heights
of &quot;occasionally not boring.&quot;
Nice work, Konami.

Who needs Silent Hill when your business strategy
can make me scared, miserable and occasionally
covered in bloodstained filth.
